qas.question: Which centre provides electives outside of science for students?
Outside of doing it on their own time, what other motivation could students have to take non mandatory electives?
Which unit is a part of the Co-Curricular Studies that offers master's degrees?
Scientists seeking a master's degree might be interested in which other degree besides Science Communication from the Science Communication Unit?
Where are elective science courses offered?
What are all students required to do on their own time?
Where can students get a degree in mass communication?

plausible_answers.text: French, German, Japanese, Italian, Russian, Spanish, Arabic and Mandarin Chinese.

qas.question: What language studies are required for students?

context: <b4_0>The <a0_0>Centre For Co-Curricular Studies<b4_0/><a0_0/> provides elective subjects and language courses outside the field of science for students in the other faculties and departments. Students are encouraged to <b5_0>take these classes<b5_0/> either for <a1_0>credit<a1_0/> or in their own time, and in some departments this is mandatory. Courses exist in a wide range of topics including philosophy, ethics in science and technology, history, modern literature and drama, art in the 20th century, film studies. Language courses are available in <b7_0>French, German, Japanese, Italian, Russian, Spanish, Arabic and Mandarin Chinese.<b7_0/> <b6_0>The Centre For Co-Curricular Studies<b6_0/> is home to the <a2_0>Science Communication Unit<a2_0/> which offers master's degrees in Science Communication and <a3_0>Science Media Production<a3_0/> for science graduates.
